titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Communications Workers of America, District 2 Arbitration Cases WAG.218
titlestmt.author: Nicole Greenhouse

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-11 11:06:53 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Communications Workers of America, District 2 Arbitration Cases
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.
did.abstract: Communications Workers of America, District 2 is responsible for servicing all CWA locals in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, and Washington DC. The collection mostly contains grievances and arbitration cases.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Communications Workers of America, District 2 is responsible for servicing all CWA locals in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, and Washington DC. The district represents workers in telecommunications, airlines, broadcast and cable television, health care, public service, printing and news media, food service, higher education and law enforcement. The district was ran by Vice President Peter G. Catucci from 1986-2008. In 2011, District 2 merged with District 13 and Edward Mooney was elected Vice President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection mostly contains grievances and arbitration cases with telecommunication companies, including C&P Telephone and AT&T, settled by the district. The collection also includes agreements.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Communications Workers of America, District 2 Arbitration Cases; WAG 218; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by the Communications Workers of America, District 2, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: A more detailed inventory is available in the repository.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2014, the archived websites were added as a series. The original finding aid was reformatted from a Word document to EAD in 2014.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by the Communications Workers of America, District 2, in 1994. The accession number associated with this gift is 1994.022.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The archived website was migrated from the California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service to the Internet Archive's Archive-It Service in November 2015. The link to California Digital Library was removed in October 2017.

Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: District 2-13 is responsible for servicing all CWA locals in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, Virginia, West Virginia, and the District of Columbia. Members are employed in many different sectors of the economy including, telecommunications; health care; higher education; manufacturing; broadcast and cable television; commercial printing and newspapers; state, local, and country government. The website contains news listings, bargaining agreements, their political action committee, and event listings.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.
